If an intervention modifies A to a new matrix B (i.e., changing the function to \\( z(t) = e^{Bt}x \\)) at time t_1, will the Laplace transform at any s depend solely on B and not on the earlier matrix A?
Explanation: The Laplace transform of \\( z(t) \\) from t_1 onwards will reflect the dynamics imposed by B, but the state's history influenced by A up to t_1 also impacts the overall transform, thereby making it dependent on both A and B.
